title: Generosity & Giving
description: Assess how aligned you feel about generosity with money

questions.text: I feel my partner and I have similar values about generosity.

therapeutic.rationale: Generosity values—how much to give, to whom, and why—reflect deep beliefs about money's purpose. Misalignment here can create ongoing friction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different generosity values often stem from different upbringings or beliefs about money. Understanding the 'why' builds respect even when you differ.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared generosity values create alignment on an important aspect of financial life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What role does generosity play in how you think about money?

questions.text: I feel comfortable with how my partner treats me when it comes to paying for things.

therapeutic.rationale: How you handle paying for things together reflects values about fairness, generosity, and gender roles. Discomfort here often signals unspoken expectations.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is uncomfortable, discuss expectations openly. Often assumptions about 'how it should be' are never articulated.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort with how you handle paying creates ease in your daily interactions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What expectations do you have about paying for things in your relationship? Are they being met?

questions.text: I trust my partner's judgment about giving money to family or friends.

therapeutic.rationale: Giving to family and friends is often a sensitive area where values and obligations intersect. Trust in your partner's judgment here prevents future conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different comfort with family giving often reflects different family dynamics. Explore the expectations each of you carries from your families.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust about giving to family creates alignment on a potentially contentious issue.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What expectations does your family have about financial help? Does your partner know?

questions.text: I feel my partner is generous with me in ways that matter.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling your partner's generosity—in whatever form matters to you—builds connection. Generosity isn't just about money; it's about giving what you have to give.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel the other's generosity, explore what form of generosity they need. The giving partner may be generous in ways the other doesn't recognize.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of receiving generosity strengthens your bond.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show generosity toward you? What generosity do you most appreciate?

questions.text: I believe we balance generosity to others with taking care of ourselves.

therapeutic.rationale: Balancing generosity with self-care prevents resentment. Couples who give beyond their means—whether to family, charity, or experiences—can create financial strain.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of balance may mean one partner feels the other is too generous or too stingy. Discuss what 'balanced' looks like to each of you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of balance between giving and self-care creates sustainable generosity.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you ever feel your generosity—or your partner's—comes at a cost to your relationship?
